Albania: Five hundred Albanian leaders, accepting an invitation to meet with an Ottoman general in Monastir, were trapped and killed in an ambush.
Argentina: Yaghan aboriginal Jemmy Button (Orundellico) taken from Tierra del Fuego to England by Robert FitzRoy on HMS Beagle
Australia:
Sturt arrived at Goolwa, having charted the Murray River.
The Black Line, a huge six-week military offensive, is launched, using moving cordons to drive all Aboriginal Tasmanians from the colony's settled districts to the Tasman Peninsula.
Belgium:
Belgian Revolution begins
Allied powers recognise Belgian independence.
Chile: Diego Portales begins to remodel Chilean institutions, converting the country into an authoritarian republic.
Colombia:
The Federation of Gran Colombia is dissolved
Rafael José de Urdaneta y Faría is Provisional Chief of the Government of the Republic of Gran Colombia
Simon Bolívar dies in Quinta de San Pedro Alejandrino near Santa Marta
France: July Revolution or French Revolution of 1830: the conservative House of Bourbon is overthrown and replaced by the more liberal Orleans Monarchy with Louis-Philippe becoming King of France. End of the Greek War of Independence; Greece wins their independence when Russia, France and Britain finally agree on the terms of the Treaty of London
Germany: Charles II, Duke of Brunswick was forced by an angry mob to flee the capital Braunschweig.
Italy: A series of uprisings along the Italian Peninsula occur, calling out for the merging of the different territories in the peninsula into one unified nation.
Philippine: Pascual Enrile y Alcedo appointed Governor-General (1830–1835)
Manila is opened to the world market
Russia: November Uprising: A group of Polish nationalists attacked Belweder Palace, the seat of the Governor-General.
Singapore:
Singapore comes under the Presidency of Bengal in India.
Robert Ibbetson was appointed as the second Governor of the Straits Settlements.
